thread.title: Monster sports new new headphones, Bluetooth speaker and Nickelodeon TV show
thread.title_full: Monster sports new new headphones, Bluetooth speaker and Nickelodeon TV show

title: Monster sports new new headphones, Bluetooth speaker and Nickelodeon TV show
text:
Cristiano Ronaldo (left) and Noel Lee, founder of Monster consumer electronics company. (Photo: Elton Anderson for Monster)
1 CONNECT 6 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Head Monster Noel Lee is looking to make a splash with a pair of new products and a Nickelodeon TV show in the works.
Today at the launch of Video & Audio Center 's new superstore in Woodland Hills, Calif., Lee will unveil a 24 karat version of Monster's recently-released BackFloat Bluetooth speaker that is waterproof and floats ($179.95) and new headphones approved by international soccer star Cristiano Ronaldo.
The first line of 2,000 limited edition 24K BackFloat speakers ($199) is headed to retail and MonsterProducts.com . "Other Bluetooth speakers say they are waterproof but they sink right to the bottom. What good is that?" Lee said. "This is a new spin on the lifestyle of being able to go to beach with it or go to the pool. You can do a speakerphone conference right on the water. People can use them in the shower."
Monster's 24 Karat BackFloat Bluetooth speaker. (Photo: Monster)
The new headphones, the ROC Sport black platinum over-ear headphones ($329.95), are part of Monster's new premium product line designed for and endorsed by international soccer star Cristiano Ronaldo. The company got serious traffic -- more than 30 million views -- this August with an online promotional video showing Ronaldo in disguise as a homeless man kicking a soccer ball in a Madrid, Spain square. "He’s the megastar of megastars," Lee said.
The headphones have a "very rich finish" and the sound "is my best work," Lee said.
Monster's ROC Sport Black Platinum headphones. (Photo: Monster)
In December, Lee begins filming a six-episode Nickelodeon series called Make It Monster with America's Got Talent host Nick Cannon, who's been a Monster product advisor for years and will be the show's producer. The two will conduct a Shark Tank -like process for young entrepreneurs for kids and teens.
Wanna-be startups can show off their inventions to Lee, Cannon and retailers. "He and I have always focused on youth," Lee said. "We’ll choose the most innovative invention and we will commit to making it and retail will stock it."
Recording artist Nick Cannon looks at a model wearing a new headphone by Monster during a new conference at the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Monday, Jan. 7, 2013. (Photo: Jae C. Hong, AP)
Monster Cable, founded by Lee in 1979, originally specialized in high-quality audio and video cables. But it became simply "Monster" as its product category expanded over the years.
Monster co-designed the Beats By Dr. Dre headphones that kickstarted the high-end stylish headphone category in 2008. Earlier this year, Lee filed suit against Beats, which was acquired by Apple in May 2014. Attorneys are still taking depositions, Lee says. "It's kind of like the calm before the storm," he said.
USA TODAY
Tech firm Monster sues Beats and founders Dre and Iovine
Follow Mike Snider on Twitter: @MikeSnider
